 I'm guessing that most abortions are chosen for convenience :( In the interest of science though here are some statistics gathered by about.com:
 
 Abortion Statistics - Decisions to Have an Abortion (U.S.)
 
 * 25.5% of women deciding to have an abortion want to postpone childbearing.
 * 21.3% of women cannot afford a baby.
 * 14.1% of women have a relationship issue or their partner does not want a child.
 * 12.2% of women are too young (their parents or others object to the pregnancy.)
 * 10.8% of women feel a child will disrupt their education or career.
 * 7.9% of women want no (more) children.
 * 3.3% of women have an abortion due to a risk to fetal health.
 * 2.8% of women have an abortion due to a risk to maternal health.
 
 This accounts for 97.9%....

 Do you think the final two fall under the "convenience" description? Those aside you are left with 91.8% of your sample abortions being for non medical reasons.
 
 Then:
 
 * 21.3% of women cannot afford a baby.
 * 14.1% of women have a relationship issue or their partner does not want a child.
 * 12.2% of women are too young (their parents or others object to the pregnancy.)
 * 7.9% of women want no (more) children.
 
 All seem sound social reasons not to proceed with a pregnancy.
 
 This one:
 
 * 10.8% of women feel a child will disrupt their education or career.
 
 Is a bit wooly as it could be moved into other categories (ie. not able to afford or postpone childbearing) so it an oddity in terms of describing "convenience".
 
 So out of that list there seems to be only one of the cited reasons that can seem as being for "convenience"- 25.5% of women deciding to have an abortion want to postpone childbearing. 
 
 So based on the figures you provided I'd challenge your inital assertion that most abortions are chosen for "convenience". I'd say the opposite is true, most abortions are not. However, if you were to chose a more objective and less provocotive term than "convenience" we might be able to examine the issue with less personal bias.

 I'm familiar with Terri Schiavo's life and EXTREMELY familiar with ALL aspects of eating disorders. In fact, I've been contemplating writing a book on the subject from a non-professional standpoint. One thing that I know for sure is that, while they may engage in self-destructive behaviors, they have no desire to die. Bulemics are typically over-achievers with control issues, poor self esteem, but don't necessarily have a distorted body-image and they certainly aren't suicidal. In Terri's case, she did have a distorted body image, but that doesn't translate into wanting to die. 
 If you'd like to know more, PM me.
